item.title: Cartesian Coordinates
item.description: what are cartesian coordinates? defining cartesian coordinates in terms of other coordinate systems Coordinate System Conversions Other polar $x=r\cos\theta$ $y=r\sin\theta$ usually used for two-dimensional space, but with an added $z$ axis, polar coordinates become cylindrical coordinates and can be used in three-dimensional space spherical $x=\rho\cos\phi\sin\theta$ $y=\rho\sin\phi\sin\theta$ $z=\rho\cos\theta$ used primarily in three-dimensional space

item.title: Chain Rule
item.description: multivariable chain rule Each variable uses other variables ex:1 $x=3r+s$ $y=r^2+12s$ $z=2x+y^3$ $$\frac{dz}{dr}=\frac{dz}{dx}\frac{dx}{dr}+\frac{dz}{dy}\frac{dy}{dr}$$ $$\frac{dz}{ds}=\frac{dz}{dx}\frac{dx}{ds}+\frac{dz}{dy}\frac{dy}{ds}$$ single variable chain rule $z=\sin{(x^2)}$ $$\frac{dz}{dx}=\cos{(x^2)}\cdot 2x$$

item.title: Cross Product
item.description: what is the cross product? The cross product is an algebraic operation that takes two equal length vectors and returns a vector (opposed to the dot product, which returns a single number also called a scalar).

item.title: Dot Product
item.description: what is the dot product? The dot product is an algebraic operation that takes two equal length vectors and returns a single number (opposed to the cross product, which returns a vector).

item.title: Double Integrals
item.description: what is a double integral? A double integral is an integral over two variables. Instead of area under the curve, a double integral produces volume under a surface.

item.title: Iterated Integrals
item.description: what is an iterated integral? An iterated integral is a set of integrals (usually [[ðŸ§² double integrals]] or [[ðŸ§² triple integrals]]) with bounds.

item.title: Linear Algebra
item.description: Material from MATH 341 @ UW-Madison and MIT OCW 18.06SC. Linear Equations Matrices

item.title: Linear Equations
item.description: Definition A linear equation is an equation whose highest variable power is 1. $3x + 2y = 0$ is linear because both variables, $x$ and $y$, are raised to the 1st power.

item.title: Matrices
item.description: Definition Matrix-matrix multiplication Size To multiply two matrices together, the number of columns of matrix #1 should be equal to the number of rows of matrix #2.

item.title: Multivariable Calculus
item.description: Dot product Cross product Chain rule Cartesian coordinates Spherical coordinates Double integrals Triple integrals Stokes’ Theorem Planes

item.title: Planes
item.description: implicit equation of a plane $$ax+by+cz+d=0$$ parametric equation of a plane $$P(x,y)=P_0+x\vec{r}_1+y\vec{r}_2$$

item.title: Spherical Coordinates
item.description: what are spherical coordinates? Spherical coordinates are one way to define a set of points in space, similar to cartesian coordinates or polar coordinates.

item.title: Stokes' Theorem
item.description: The line integrals of a vector field over a loop is equal to the flux of its curl through the enclosed surface.

item.title: Triple Integrals
item.description: what is a triple integral? A triple integral is an integral over three variables. Whereas a double integral can find volume or area, a triple integral can only find volume (and is sometimes used to find density).

item.title: Vectors
item.description: Definition Collinearity Two vectors are collinear if they lie on the same or parallel lines– when the vectors have the same slope.
